top.value:
Ethiopia ranks 157 in the 2010 Human Development Index. Pastoralism is an important livelihood strategy in Ethiopia with pastoralists representing 13% of the population, occupying 65% of the land and contributing 15% of GDP. However, pastoralist communities are particularly vulnerable to food insecurity due to environmental factors, market and finance limitations, and lack of organisation, low bargaining power and a policy environment that often neglects the specific needs and potential contribution of pastoralist communities. The JEP January 2010 livelihoods baseline study revealed only 8% of male-headed households (MHH) and 1% of female headed households (FHH) in Borana own sufficient animals for sustainable livelihoods, yet livestock is the primary income source of 65% of MHH and 39% FHH. Moreover 20% MHH and 23% of FHH have no second source of income, and more than half have no third source. The average value of assets held by MHH is £55, and FHH £36, highlighting vulnerability generally, but particularly for FHH. Gender-related development indicators continue to show the high impact of gender inequalities in literacy rates, participation in economic and political life and access to income. This means unequal access to the assets needed to sustain or develop livelihoods. Marketing is constrained by poor infrastructure, compounded by lack of dissemination of market information and financing opportunities. Poor pastoralists lack inputs to diversify and add value to their products which puts them at a disadvantage in a competitive market. Lack of business skills further limits the capacity of poor pastoralists to participate in markets to their full potential. The government seeks to support poor pastoralists in livelihoods development and income generation through the cooperatives approach, but the ability of the Cooperative Promotion Offices (CPO) at district level to effectively support individual cooperatives is limited by lack of logistical capacity and high staff turnover. 

The key target group are the members of the saving and credit groups (SACCOs), the members of the processing and marketing cooperatives, and small scale traders and entrepreneurs. There is a strong focus on SACCOs as these have lower entry levels and high female membership.
¬
The TRADE in Borana project is a consortium project to be implemented by AFD, SOS Sahel and GPDI. It is focused on diversifying and increasing the livelihood options of poor pastoralist communities. AFD is working with cooperatives in Borana Zone to develop them as credible business entities that enhance the local economy and enable their members to gain skills and networks for successful marketing and income generation. AFD’s expertise in establishing and capacitating SACCOs is well recognised in Borana, and they bring extensive experience, aiming for a fivefold increase in membership during the project life and increased organisational capacity to provide credit and support services to their members. AFD will also provide Alternative Basic Education (ABE) which provides essential skills to cooperative members and individuals seeking to develop their small scale businesses.

The other partners to the project have complementary activities in different districts of Borana. GPDI will focus on building the capacity of cooperatives to generate income from livestock and will contribute to the work with local traders and businesses. GPDI will also bring specific expertise on animal fattening as a means of adding value to livestock assets and generating increased income from marketing. This will have strong focus on research and allowing best practice to be expanded. They will also work on providing credit through SACCOs. GPDI’s knowledge and understanding of the Borana Gada and traditional livestock management and marketing systems will add particular value to project activities targeting the livestock sector. SOS Sahel has extensive experience in promoting the value chain approach alongside sustainable natural resource management and offers expertise and leadership in participatory development processes at community level. SOS Sahel will lead on the development of a zone-level Union and Bio-Enterprise Centre to link producers and buyers in a manner that allows increasing and sustainable profits for the producer. The BEC will also provide support with product processing, packaging and labelling. SOS Sahel will provide support services and training for cooperatives processing and marketing non-timber forest products in Borana.

Humanitarian needs are pervasive across South Sudan as a result of multiple threats, including armed conflict, inter-communal violence, economic decline, disease and climatic changes. Despite the signing of a peace agreement between warring sides in August 2015, the impact of violence on civilians has been catastrophic. Large sections of the population are displaced and often multiple times due to repeated attacks by different armed forces. As of Feb 2017, 2.2million people are internally displaced, and approximately 1.5 million have fled violence as refugees into neighbouring countries. Over 600,000 children are reported acutely malnourished. Protection for civilians is of particular concern: acts of physical and sexual violence against women, and recruitment of children into armed groups are widespread.
CTP proposes to work with Caritas Diocese of Rumbek. CTP has partnered with CDoR for Phase I and II of the Yirol emergency response and has implemented a close-accompaniment model, as CTP technical staff work side by side with CDoR programme staff in the implementation of key FSL and WASH activities. This approach has ensured standards in quality and accountability are reached and maintained, and the technical capacity of partner staff is gradually built through on-job training. Organisational weaknesses in financial management identified by CTP demand a similar approach. CTP has retained management of large-scale procurement until the capacity of CDoR is sufficient to enable them undertake procurement independently. CTP is implementing an organisational development plan over 18 months to enable engender this further. 
It is planned that Trócaire’s protection advisors will work closely ensuring appropriate protection mechanisms are implemented and global protection cluster standards, and those of the protection cluster in South Sudan, are followed. Capacity building on protection standards and conflict sensitive approaches for CDoR will also underpin this.

CAFOD’s long standing partner, CPDMM the Programme for Development and Peace of the Magdalena Medio Region, with national coordination with CINEP, together with CAFOD will implement this project on peace education and culture in Colombia with a youth and gender focus.
Working with 4956 young people and adults (with 52% women and 48% men) in 9 municipalities in the Madgalena Medio Region the project will contribute to an individual and collective peace building and reconciliation culture. It will strengthen the capacities of youth, civil society organizations (CSO), communities and local public institutions to promote peace education and culture, civic coexistence, social solidarity attuned to the environment.
This will be achieved through (1) transforming knowledge, attitudes and  behaviours of adolescents, young people, parents and teachers in 34 schools and promoting peace education and culture, reconciliation, conflict prevention, and peaceful coexistence in their relationships and with their environment, (2) working with civil society organizations and local communities in the Magdalena Medio region to implement pedagogical and cultural initiatives for the transformation of behaviours and to foster peace building and reconciliation, active citizenship and gender equality, as well as social solidarity attuned to the environment and (3) by promoting and disseminating experiences and methodologies  of positive conflict  transformation and the construction of a sustainable regional development through spaces of coexistence, dialogue and inter-sectorial negotiation, with citizen participation.

Currently the Muslim community, which makes up 4.3% of the population (2014 census), is disconnected in its intra-faith understanding and promotion of minority rights. To foster a culture of peace between different faith communities, it is essential that grassroots Islamic leaders and the Muslim community have an increased understanding of their rights as a religious minority. This project will bring together Muslims from different denominations through dialogues, trainings and exposure visits focusing on self-awareness, tolerance and non-violence leading to a greater understanding of themselves and their rights as a minority group. 

Using a rights-based approach, this project will equip and empower Muslim leaders and communities with the knowledge and skills to develop action plans to protect and promote their rights with a united voice. Developing a common understanding of faith and religion (including theology, context and a rights perspective) within each group is a key step to engaging in constructive inter-faith dialogues, and therefore contributing to functional coexistence and a culture of peace.

For the two past decades the Eastern part of The DRC has under gone  several political unrest. Such tensed situation has left new generation without inspiration. Clashes between different groups has characterised the mind-set of the population, which is dictating the attitude of the population; Local structures such as intercommunity ‘Barza’ and youth clubs have been politicized .  Many youth have lost their lives due to some selfish political manipulation that feed their interest. As we approach the election, the Commission of Justice and Peace in Goma ‘CDJP’ intends to inform youth of their rights and obligation. J P Commission will target these structures and will strengthen sensitisation with all possible media, recreation activities, training, open dialogues and conferences and debates  with pretended candidates, voters and intercommunity groups of youth and influential leaders in Goma, Sake and Rutshuru in the effort to prevent the escalation of violence.  
The Catholic Church that raised voice for peace and respect of the Constitution remains credible for presidential and opposition political parties. Through this project , Justice and Peace Commission’s at the national will seek to tackle this unstable context by preparing youths, marginalized and women to avoid tensions, manipulations in the upcoming challenging elections. People need fairly-elected leaders to deliver basic services, and improve security issues around the country. This project aims to improve knowledge about the election process by disseminating programs of voter and civic education, starting now before the local elections and continuing throughout the election process and ensure that the material used is accurate and politically neutral. The Project plans to use sport and music to bring youth together and help them understand the importance of peaceful elections process and how to peacefully claim its rights. SMS messaging  will also be used for democratization process within the church.

From 24th  of  August 2018, torrential rains caused serious flooding in 12 states in Nigeria. 250-500 mm total rain fall was recorded in one month starting from 24th of August till 23rd September and this caused severe damage to public and private infrastructure and wiped out people's livelihoods. 13000 houses partly and fully damaged in extremely affected 4 target states of Anambra, Delta, Kogi and Niger. 122650 hectares of agricultural land has been affected and standing crops have been destroyed leaving affected population with looming food security crises in coming weeks and months. (Source ACAPS Update 26th September) 
In the 12 states, flooding has impacted 826,403 people and out of the total affected population 176,299 people are forced to be displaced in 10 out of 12 states affected. Among the 12 states affected by flooding in Nigeria, 4 states (Niger, Kogi, Anambra and Delta) have been declared as National Disaster by Federal Government of Nigeria: 
The consortium (Christian Aid, CARE International and CAFOD ) is well positioned to intervene in those 4 states and are ready to do so.  Based on the data collected from the field under the supervision of the National Emergency Management Agency, which coordinates humanitarian action, the total of affected people in these 4 states is nearly 489,087. This project aims to provide emergency assistance through unconditional cash to 3600 extremelly affected and vulnerable families of 3 severely affected (Anambra, Kogi and Delta) states. CAFOD will specifically intervene in four LGAs in Kogi state; Kogi, Lokoja, Bassa and Omala. We will reach 1204HH in the four LGAs by providing unconditional cash transfer to the target HHs. Other add on activities would include WASH sensitization, protection mainstreaming/CRM and community mobilization, advocacy visits to National Emergency Management Agency/State Emergency Management Agencies( NEMA/SEMA), the government agency responsible for emergency response in Nigeria

Agenda 2030 (which includes the Sustainable Development Goals – SDGs) includes transformational shifts for how the international community approaches sustainable development. These include leaving no-one behind, protecting the environment, deepening participation and tackling inequality. These correspond closely with key aspects of Catholic Social Teaching: preferential option for the poor, care for our common home and people as artisans of their own destiny – all emphasised in Laudato Si’. It brings together the cry of the poor and the cry of the earth.

CAFOD has been working since last year on a civic education project aimed at promoting the participation of the population in the democratic process. This project was funded by Porticus and implemented in the dioceses of Kinshasa, Bukavu and Goma.
DRCongo faces political and human rights challenges in relation to the undelivered election. President Joseph Kabila, who was supposed to step at the end of his second and last term, did not do so, and as a result, the opposition has intensified the pressure to protest this tendency. The democratic space and human rights is seriously reduced.
The Catholic Church, through the Justice and Peace Commission at the national level (CEJP) and the diocesan (CDJP Goma and CDJP Bukavu) sought to address this unstable environment by preparing young women and men to swiftly play their civic role. The objective of this project was to improve the public's knowledge on the electoral process by disseminating civic and electoral education programs in preparation for the elections by ensuring that the materials and tools used are politically acceptable. The project also planned to use sport and music to bring young people together and help them understand the importance of a peaceful electoral process and, above all, how to peacefully claim their rights. In addition, the project also planned to use social media to inform the youth about the democratization process and the role of youth in the political process.
It is with this in mind that we plan to undertake a final evaluation and audit to assess and sanction the effectiveness and efficiency of this project so that we can better direct the rest of our interventions related to citizen participation in the political process in three dioceses. We seek to evaluate the impact and efficiency of our interventions for the benefit of the aforementioned dioceses, analyze the socio-political and security factors in this context in order to better guide our future programs.
This project will also facilitate the evaluation and audit of the social Integration project of the youth at risk and ex combatants that was also funded by Porticus over the past 3 years.

Caritas Norway, in cooperation with the Catholic Agency for Overseas Development (CAFOD) and Trocaire in Partnership (CTP) and Catholic Diocese of Rumbek (CDoR), Lakes State, will provide improved food security to 5400 IDPs and vulnerable host community members, with a strong focus on empowerment of women. The project will also support conflict prevention and peace building through dialogue and reconciliation activities aligned with the peace work at national level centred on the support to South Sudan Council of Churches and their peace initiatives. This project will provide one of the very sparse humanitarian interventions in the severely underserved target area.

Part of the Match Fund 4 project (including projects in DRC and Uganda) this project aims to increase sustainable access to improved WASH facilities in rural disadvantaged communities in Zimbabwe. We will directly provide WASH services alongside investing in social mobilisation of communities to influence local government on policy implementation, and strengthen water user groups to adopt correct use and maintenance of water points.
The beneficiary communities were selected due to their high levels of vulnerability to droughts and inadequate access to WASH services and facilities. These target groups also experience interrupted access to clean drinking water due to non-functional hand pumps. Specific groups to be reached within the selected underserved communities include women and men in underserved villages including female headed households, the elderly, people with disabilities, and people living with HIV/AIDS.
The targeted districts Binga and Gokwe are among the poorest and most marginalised areas of Zimbabwe, prone to food insecurity and with very poor infrastructure and service provision. These areas are geographically remote with very poor soils and arid landscapes, characterised by livestock rearing as the main livelihoods option, with a consequently widely-spaced population; hence difficult to access for service provision. As a consequence of limited access to adequate WASH services, communities in these districts are very vulnerable to diarrhoea. 
The livelihoods of the local population are also heavily affected by the water access restrictions. Livestock rearing, the main livelihoods activity, is hindered by the difficulty in reaching reliable sources of drinking water.

A weak economy and poor institutional capacity are leading to inadequate water sector investment, inappropriate use of water supply technologies and are contributing to depleting the communities’ skill base. The situation is exacerbated by the absence of a holistic and coordinated approach to water and land management in the target districts. Water resources are currently managed by different government ministries, resulting in a lack of sector coordination.

Despite efforts to improve rural WASH provision in Zimbabwe, significant gaps remain, particularly in hard-to-reach and historically under-served areas with the additional geological and technical challenges. Coordination with other sector actors takes place at ward, district, provincial and national level; CAFOD and partners participate in these forums. This project is in line with the Zimbabwe National Sanitation and Hygiene Strategy , which states that public funds would focus, amongst other areas, on construction and management of institutional sanitation in schools, clinics, markets and other public places.
